<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
VIDEOGAMES
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/11/sony-microsoft-take-different-approaches-latest-console-war?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Sony and Microsoft Go Head-to-Head, Again
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Sony PlayStation 5" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=405 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/V6Y9IpDepemUB9IWbd/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Sony PlayStation 5" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/V6Y9IpDepemUB9IWbd/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy/Sony</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">With the launch of the Sony PlayStation 5 today and Microsoft’s Xbox Series X and S on Tuesday, this week marks harmonic convergence of the console giants all over again—an endless cycle of hyped hardware releases that occurs every eight-ish years. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Here’s the rundown on the two warring tech companies and how they’re approaching the growing gaming industry.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Choose your weapon: Sony</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>Spider-Man: Miles Morales</em>, <em>Demon’s Souls</em>, and more...Sony is launching the PS5 with an impressive lineup of popular titles to entice buyers. The towering console (judging by its <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/9/16/21438782/sony-ps5-size-specs-dimensions-console-huge-large-big?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">historic size</a>, it ate all its predecessors) is also being hailed for its controller, which apparently <a href="https://www.wired.com/review/playstation-5/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rumbles</a> players’ hands into the fourth dimension.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Sony continues to be the hardware leader for die-hard gamers. DFC Intelligence predicts PlayStation 5 sales <a href="https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/playstation-5-xbox-series-x-sony-microsoft-console-wars-1234811640/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">will double</a> those for the new Xbox, a big but narrower margin than the 113.7 million PlayStation 4s sold compared to 48.4 Xbox Ones. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Plus, Sony has a more advanced virtual reality headset reportedly </span><span><a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/psvr-on-ps5-everything-you-need-to-know/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">in the works</a></span><span> for when gamers’ wallets recover.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Choose your weapon: Microsoft</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Execs don’t seem to be sweating Sony’s hardware advantage. Why? Monthly subscriptions are becoming the unit’s bread and butter. A <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/erikkain/2020/11/10/xbox-series-x-vs-playstation-5-microsoft-has-2-huge-advantages-over-sony/?sh=31675e6d5274&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new offering</a> called “All Access” lets gamers pay for the new Xbox in monthly installments, and—here’s the kicker—also signs them up for Xbox’s Netflix-like Game Pass Ultimate gaming subscription service.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Microsoft wants to turn one-time console buyers into lifetime customers who, instead of buying a physical Xbox, could eventually opt to use xCloud, Microsoft's cloud gaming service. (Learn more about that bag of chips <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/10/cloud-gaming-big-tech-streaming-wars?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">here</a>.)</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>this week, Sony and Microsoft both released high-tech consoles that, as far as the actual hardware specs go, are pretty on-par with each other. But, while both gaming giants sell subscription services and hardware, Microsoft is focusing on recurring payments.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">P.S. </strong>Neither Sony nor Microsoft is expected to sell the most consoles this holiday season. That award will likely go to the three-year-old Nintendo Switch.</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/11/disney-turns-1-howd?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Happy First Birthday to This Little Guy
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Baby Yoda" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/KziKCpvrGngHbYjaUF/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Baby Yoda" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/KziKCpvrGngHbYjaUF/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">One year ago, Disney’s big bet on streaming went live in a blaze of wrinkly green glory. And on a scale of Quibi to Zoom, it definitely netted out as a pandemic winner. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What happened? </strong>Disney+ was supposed to be one of many games in town for entertainment giant Disney, but soon became the <a href="https://www.theringer.com/tv/2020/10/26/21534395/disney-plus-covid-19-streaming-wars?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>only </em>game</a> when Covid-19 hammered theme park revenues and film releases. Over the summer, Disney+ became the new home for films like <em>Mulan </em>and <em>Hamilton</em>, which had originally been intended for that ancient relic known as a “movie theater.”</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Analysts were skeptical Disney+ would hit its target of 60–90 million subscribers by 2024. But as of August, it already passed 60 million. Even Netflix CEO Reed Hastings conceded it was “super-impressive execution.”</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But don’t sleep on the competition,<strong style="color:#000"> </strong>from Netflix with 167 million subscribers to newer entrants like HBO Max (57 million subscribers globally), NBCUniversal’s Peacock (22 million), and Apple TV+, whose 1-year anniversary was <a href="https://www.theverge.com/21541153/apple-tv-plus-one-year-anniversary-bundle-apple-one-price-trial?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">11 days ago</a>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>while the pandemic delayed production timelines, Disney+ expects to release more original content next year, including—what else—more Marvel and Star Wars series. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ Flash poll:</strong> Is Baby Yoda cute? Y/N</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SOCIAL MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/11/tiktok-complains-us-government-went-silent-divestiture-deadline?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
When You’re a Company, You Have Legal Recourse for Ghosting
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On Thursdays, we throw back...to warmer months. Chinese-owned video sharing giant TikTok, whose potential sale <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/13/china-reportedly-will-block-tiktok-sale?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">dominated</a> <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/08/03/chinese-government-citizens-attack-proposed-tiktok-sale?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">the news</a> <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/marketing/stories/2020/08/12/tiktok-saga-continues?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">over the summer</a>, returned to the headlines with a court petition <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/11/10/21559677/tiktok-cfius-court-petition-ban-deadline?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">filed</a> on Tuesday. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>In August, President Trump signed an executive order forcing TikTok to either sell itself to an American company or face a ban over national security concerns. In September, software firm Oracle and megaretailer Walmart proposed a deal to partner with a new, U.S.-based company called TikTok Global. The government <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/tiktok-continues-to-seek-delay-in-sale-deadline-11605117079?mod=pls_whats_news_us_business_f&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">seemed</a> to sign off, at least in theory. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Now, TikTok owner ByteDance says the U.S. government left it on read. In its petition, the company said CFIUS (the Committee on Foreign Investment in the U.S., which handles issues of foreign ownership) had stopped communicating—and the deadline for ByteDance to divest its stake in TikTok is today. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>It’s not clear what happens when that deadline passes. ByteDance applied for a 30-day extension, but says it hasn’t heard anything. </p>

</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/11/facebook-google-extend-broad-sweeping-bans-political-ads?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Facebook and Google Get the Ban Back Together
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Seinfeld saying "I'm banned?"" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=486 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/eAKlNC04fh8Le6pifS/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Seinfeld saying " I'm banned?"" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/eAKlNC04fh8Le6pifS/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Much like we had planned to always wear pants while working, Facebook and Google had planned to lift their bans on political advertising one week after the election concluded. But yesterday we wrote this in boxers, and both platforms <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/facebook-and-google-extend-bans-on-political-ads-11605114915?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">extended their bans</a> for the next few weeks. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The argument for:</strong> Allegations of voter fraud continue to circulate on social media despite state election officials from both parties finding <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/10/us/politics/voting-fraud.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">no evidence</a> to support those claims, per the NYT. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In an email to advertisers, Facebook said, “While multiple sources have projected a presidential winner”—this would be Joe Biden—“we still believe it’s important to help prevent confusion or abuse on our platform.”</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The argument against: </strong>Banning political advertising ahead of two runoff Senate elections in Georgia is like using a “rusty ax” for “something that deserves a scalpel,” Republican digital strategist Eric Wilson <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-social-media/facebook-extends-ban-on-u-s-political-ads-for-another-month-idUSKBN27R23Y?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told Reuters</a>. Some Dems agree—a blanket ban makes it difficult for candidates of either party to rally support online. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> Critics argue the ad ban doesn’t address the real issue afflicting social media—the spread of misinformation in unpaid, organic posts. </p>

<small><em>Patrick Smith/Getty Images. Look at Dustin's wrist position!</em></small>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Masters golf tournament tees off today at Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you play golf, you’re probably used to waiting around...but not for this long. The Masters, which is typically held in April and is synonymous with spring, was pushed back seven months because of the pandemic. That means we'll have to accept fall foliage in place of flowering azaleas.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A few interesting notes ahead of the tournament: </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>There won’t be patrons this year because of Covid, but </span><span><a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/masters-food-pimento-cheese-sandwich-prices-augusta-national-2019-4#the-menu-at-augusta-national-is-tough-to-beat-1?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">check out the prices</a></span><span> for food and drink at Augusta. $3 for a chicken wrap! </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Now in its 65th consecutive year airing on CBS, The Masters is the </span><span><a href="https://frontofficesports.com/bryson-dechambeau-masters-cbs-1st-hole-nick-faldo-jim-nantz-dottie-pepper/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">longest-running sporting event</a></span><span> broadcast by a single network, per Front Office Sports.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Bryson DeChambeau, </span><span><a href="https://twitter.com/david_perell/status/1307811967428702208?s=20&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">golf innovator</a></span><span>, is the consensus favorite at 8-1 odds. The Brew's pick? Tony Finau. </span>
</li>
</ul>

<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>"Can’t decide what to stream? <li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>"Scientists </span><span><a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/astronomers-discover-hell-planet-k2-141b-rock-rain-lava-oceans/?ftag=CNM-00-10aab7e&linkId=103730842&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">discover</a></span><span> bizarre hell planet where it rains rocks and oceans are made of lava"</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>"'It's the screams of the damned!' The </span><span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2020/nov/09/deepfake-pop-music-artificial-intelligence-ai-frank-sinatra?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">eerie AI world</a></span><span> of deepfake music"</span>
</li>

<span>"Hardware store in Erie </span><span><a href="https://media.giphy.com/media/UojXG4ZbjQeVnHluzN/giphy.gif?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">boycotted</a></span><span> for selling holiday-themed jumpers and playing Christmas music 'too early'"</span>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nSony and Microsoft Go Head-to-Head, Again\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if mso]\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Sony PlayStation 5\" style=\"display: block; --\u003e\n\u003cimg class=\"story-header-image\" alt=\"Sony PlayStation 5\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/V6Y9IpDepemUB9IWbd/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy/Sony\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWith the launch of the Sony PlayStation 5 today and Microsoft’s Xbox Series X and S on Tuesday, this week marks harmonic convergence of the console giants all over again—an endless cycle of hyped hardware releases that occurs every eight-ish years. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHere’s the rundown on the two warring tech companies and how they’re approaching the growing gaming industry.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eChoose your weapon: Sony\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eSpider-Man: Miles Morales\u003c/em\u003e, \u003cem\u003eDemon’s Souls\u003c/em\u003e, and more...Sony is launching the PS5 with an impressive lineup of popular titles to entice buyers. The towering console (judging by its \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/9/16/21438782/sony-ps5-size-specs-dimensions-console-huge-large-big?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehistoric size\u003c/a\u003e, it ate all its predecessors) is also being hailed for its controller, which apparently \u003ca href=\"https://www.wired.com/review/playstation-5/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erumbles\u003c/a\u003e players’ hands into the fourth dimension.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSony continues to be the hardware leader for die-hard gamers. DFC Intelligence predicts PlayStation 5 sales \u003ca href=\"https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/playstation-5-xbox-series-x-sony-microsoft-console-wars-1234811640/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewill double\u003c/a\u003e those for the new Xbox, a big but narrower margin than the 113.7 million PlayStation 4s sold compared to 48.4 Xbox Ones. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003ePlus, Sony has a more advanced virtual reality headset reportedly \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnet.com/news/psvr-on-ps5-everything-you-need-to-know/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ein the works\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e for when gamers’ wallets recover.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eChoose your weapon: Microsoft\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eExecs don’t seem to be sweating Sony’s hardware advantage. Why? Monthly subscriptions are becoming the unit’s bread and butter. A \u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/erikkain/2020/11/10/xbox-series-x-vs-playstation-5-microsoft-has-2-huge-advantages-over-sony/?sh=31675e6d5274\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enew offering\u003c/a\u003e called “All Access” lets gamers pay for the new Xbox in monthly installments, and—here’s the kicker—also signs them up for Xbox’s Netflix-like Game Pass Ultimate gaming subscription service.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eMicrosoft wants to turn one-time console buyers into lifetime customers who, instead of buying a physical Xbox, could eventually opt to use xCloud, Microsoft's cloud gaming service. (Learn more about that bag of chips \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/10/cloud-gaming-big-tech-streaming-wars?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e.)\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethis week, Sony and Microsoft both released high-tech consoles that, as far as the actual hardware specs go, are pretty on-par with each other. But, while both gaming giants sell subscription services and hardware, Microsoft is focusing on recurring payments.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eP.S. \u003c/strong\u003eNeither Sony nor Microsoft is expected to sell the most consoles this holiday season. That award will likely go to the three-year-old Nintendo Switch.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOne year ago, Disney’s big bet on streaming went live in a blaze of wrinkly green glory. And on a scale of Quibi to Zoom, it definitely netted out as a pandemic winner. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat happened? \u003c/strong\u003eDisney+ was supposed to be one of many games in town for entertainment giant Disney, but soon became the \u003ca href=\"https://www.theringer.com/tv/2020/10/26/21534395/disney-plus-covid-19-streaming-wars?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eonly \u003c/em\u003egame\u003c/a\u003e when Covid-19 hammered theme park revenues and film releases. Over the summer, Disney+ became the new home for films like \u003cem\u003eMulan \u003c/em\u003eand \u003cem\u003eHamilton\u003c/em\u003e, which had originally been intended for that ancient relic known as a “movie theater.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAnalysts were skeptical Disney+ would hit its target of 60–90 million subscribers by 2024. But as of August, it already passed 60 million. Even Netflix CEO Reed Hastings conceded it was “super-impressive execution.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut don’t sleep on the competition,\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e \u003c/strong\u003efrom Netflix with 167 million subscribers to newer entrants like HBO Max (57 million subscribers globally), NBCUniversal’s Peacock (22 million), and Apple TV+, whose 1-year anniversary was \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/21541153/apple-tv-plus-one-year-anniversary-bundle-apple-one-price-trial?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e11 days ago\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ewhile the pandemic delayed production timelines, Disney+ expects to release more original content next year, including—what else—more Marvel and Star Wars series. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ Flash poll:\u003c/strong\u003e Is Baby Yoda cute? style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn Thursdays, we throw back...to warmer months. Chinese-owned video sharing giant TikTok, whose potential sale \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/13/china-reportedly-will-block-tiktok-sale?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edominated\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/08/03/chinese-government-citizens-attack-proposed-tiktok-sale?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethe news\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/marketing/stories/2020/08/12/tiktok-saga-continues?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eover the summer\u003c/a\u003e, returned to the headlines with a court petition \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/11/10/21559677/tiktok-cfius-court-petition-ban-deadline?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efiled\u003c/a\u003e on Tuesday. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eIn August, President Trump signed an executive order forcing TikTok to either sell itself to an American company or face a ban over national security concerns. In September, software firm Oracle and megaretailer Walmart proposed a deal to partner with a new, U.S.-based company called TikTok Global. The government \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/tiktok-continues-to-seek-delay-in-sale-deadline-11605117079?mod=pls_whats_news_us_business_f\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eseemed\u003c/a\u003e to sign off, at least in theory. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNow, TikTok owner ByteDance says the U.S. government left it on read. In its petition, the company said CFIUS (the Committee on Foreign Investment in the U.S., which handles issues of foreign ownership) had stopped communicating—and the deadline for ByteDance to divest its stake in TikTok is today. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eIt’s not clear what happens when that deadline passes. ByteDance applied for a 30-day extension, but says it hasn’t heard anything. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" Together\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if mso]\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Seinfeld saying \"I'm banned?\"\" !mso]\u003e--\u003e\u003c!-- --\u003e\n\u003cimg class=\"story-header-image\" alt=\"Seinfeld saying \"I'm banned?\"\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/eAKlNC04fh8Le6pifS/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eMuch like we had planned to always wear pants while working, Facebook and Google had planned to lift their bans on political advertising one week after the election concluded. But yesterday we wrote this in boxers, and both platforms \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/facebook-and-google-extend-bans-on-political-ads-11605114915?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eextended their bans\u003c/a\u003e for the next few weeks. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe argument for:\u003c/strong\u003e Allegations of voter fraud continue to circulate on social media despite state election officials from both parties finding \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/10/us/politics/voting-fraud.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eno evidence\u003c/a\u003e to support those claims, per the NYT. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn an email to advertisers, Facebook said, “While multiple sources have projected a presidential winner”—this would be Joe Biden—“we still believe it’s important to help prevent confusion or abuse on our platform.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe argument against: \u003c/strong\u003eBanning political advertising ahead of two runoff Senate elections in Georgia is like using a “rusty ax” for “something that deserves a scalpel,” Republican digital strategist Eric Wilson \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-social-media/facebook-extends-ban-on-u-s-political-ads-for-another-month-idUSKBN27R23Y?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etold Reuters\u003c/a\u003e. Some Dems agree—a blanket ban makes it difficult for candidates of either party to rally support online. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e Critics argue the ad ban doesn’t address the real issue afflicting social media—the spread of misinformation in unpaid, organic posts. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F11%2F11%2Ffacebook-google-extend-broad-sweeping-bans-political-ads\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block;
